docs.lead_paragraph: CARLOS SAURA'S fascination with the past has led him to the Oedipal impasse of ''Sweet Hours,'' a film about a man who longs hopelessly for his own boyhood. The film initially shows Juan (Inaki Aierra) in a subdued, languid mood, but it traces the ever more intense process by which he rediscovers his memories. A packet of his parents' old letters triggers Juan's desire to re-create his experience with his mother, whom his father abandoned. This mother-son relationship, we discover, was a pure, happy, sexy passion of the sort few men experience with their grown-up mates, let alone with their moms. ''Haven't you been to a psychiatrist?'' Berta asks him. Not a bad question. Berta is an ever-smiling, accommodating-looking actress Juan has hired to impersonate his mother, in a drama he is creating about his own family. While actors play his mother, aunt, uncle, grandma, baby sister and so on, as they were during World War II, a grown-up Juan plays himself as a boy. (Woody Allen attempted something similar, albeit for comic purposes, as a grown-up version of himself in the schoolroom scene of ''Annie Hall.'')
